resource.http://dev.llgc.org.uk/sas/full_text:
Il Lesso (Boiled Meat) 

This is the most popular dish in the bourgeois kitchens of the 18th-century Venice and was prepared with different kinds of meat, especially capon, chicken, turkey, breast and head of veal, mutton and sheep. Meats with a few pieces of bone were placed in a pot with cold water, flavored with a clove-studded onion, one or more stalks of celery, a few carrots, parsley stalks, and one or more cloves of garlic. Once cooked, the meats were kept warm in a nice copper pot, immersed in their broth. When it was time to serve them, they were sent to the table accompanied by special sauces.
resource.chars:
Il Lesso (Boiled Meat) 

This is the most popular dish in the bourgeois kitchens of the 18th-century Venice and was prepared with different kinds of meat, especially capon, chicken, turkey, breast and head of veal, mutton and sheep. Meats with a few pieces of bone were placed in a pot with cold water, flavored with a clove-studded onion, one or more stalks of celery, a few carrots, parsley stalks, and one or more cloves of garlic. Once cooked, the meats were kept warm in a nice copper pot, immersed in their broth. When it was time to serve them, they were sent to the table accompanied by special sauces.

item.value: <svg xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><path xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" d="M720.38281,869.88757h44.63636v0h44.63636v24.63636v24.63636h-44.63636h-44.63636v-24.63636z" data-paper-data="{"strokeWidth":1,"rotation":0,"deleteIcon":null,"rotationIcon":null,"group":null,"editable":true,"annotation":null}" id="rectangle_c3e0272a-7642-4bde-9417-8f29d61731ff" fill-opacity="0" fill="#00bfff" fill-rule="nonzero" stroke="#00bfff" stroke-width="1" stroke-linecap="butt" stroke-linejoin="miter" stroke-miterlimit="10" stroke-dasharray="" stroke-dashoffset="0" font-family="none" font-weight="none" font-size="none" text-anchor="none" style="mix-blend-mode: normal"/></svg>

resource.http://dev.llgc.org.uk/sas/full_text:
La salsa par el lesso (Boiled Meat Sauce)

Sauces for boiled meat have also evolved and now cren (horseradish), salsa verde (a cold parsley-based condiment) and mustard are used, but in the 18th century, as Giuseppe Maffioli diligently points out, they were very different:

  1. A salted and well pounded pilchard and a little garlic, you take a little oil and dilute, add lemon juice and vinegar and mix it all with breadcrumbs and parsley (chopped). Care must be taken that it does not come out too liquid or too thick.
  2. (Spicy) Three salted pilchards, two hard-boiled egg yolks, everything is pounded well. It is diluted with a little oil, vinegar (a lot), pepper and lemon.
  3. In a small bowl put one egg and one tablespoon of sugar. Beat well. When frothy add a tumbler of vinegar, then transfer to the fire and cook like an eggnog. It is used as well cold as hot. Add a level tablespoon of capers.
  4. A handful of white flour is boiled in water or broth to form a floured liquid. Well pounded anchovies and a small piece of butter, salt, spices and the tartness of a lemon are added. It is simmered for another 3 or 4 minutes and sent to the table hot.

  2. (Spicy) Three salted pilchards, two hard-boiled egg yolks, everything is pounded well. It is diluted with a little oil, vinegar (a lot), pepper and lemon.
  3. In a small bowl put one egg and one tablespoon of sugar. Beat well. When frothy add a tumbler of vinegar, then transfer to the fire and cook like an eggnog. It is used as well cold as hot. Add a level tablespoon of capers.
  4. A handful of white flour is boiled in water or broth to form a floured liquid. Well pounded anchovies and a small piece of butter, salt, spices and the tartness of a lemon are added. It is simmered for another 3 or 4 minutes and sent to the table hot.

resource.http://dev.llgc.org.uk/sas/full_text:
La Frittura (Fried Food)

Many dishes were prepared with this technique in Venice: first of all, fish, which could be of a single quality, such as sardines, sardoni, sfogi, passarini, little mullets, cuttlefish, squid, etc., or of more than one species, resulting in the famous mixed fried foods still popular in Venetian cuisine today. Then there were fried giblets, such as brains, livers, etc.; but also vegetables, such as castraure (artichokes of first flower), zucchini slices, squash blossoms, mushrooms, etc. However, the cooking technique was almost always the same: you would pass the piece to be fried to white flour, then to egg and breadcrumbs and dip it in a very hot fat, which was oil, butter or lard. It was immediately sent to the table, with a sprinkle of salt and, if you liked it, a few drops of lemon.

Then there were fried giblets, such as brains, livers, etc.; but also vegetables, such as castraure (artichokes of first flower), zucchini slices, squash blossoms, mushrooms, etc. However, the cooking technique was almost always the same: you would pass the piece to be fried to white flour, then to egg and breadcrumbs and dip it in a very hot fat, which was oil, butter or lard. It was immediately sent to the table, with a sprinkle of salt and, if you liked it, a few drops of lemon.

resource.http://dev.llgc.org.uk/sas/full_text:
La Minestra (Soup)

This dish was customary when boiled meat arrived on the table immediately afterwards. When the meat was cooked and removed from the broth, it was pureed or at any rate the vegetables and any meat residue were also carefully removed, brought back to a boil, and rice or pasta was added, which was then brought to a simmer. The pasta was generally egg pasta, homemade, of a rather thin format, like tagliatelle or thin, fairly short bigoli. It was flavored at the end with plenty of grated piazentin cheese or even parmesan or old local dairy and sent to the table.

It was flavored at the end with plenty of grated piazentin cheese or even parmesan or old local dairy and sent to the table.

La salsa par el lesso (Boiled Meat Sauce)

Sauces for boiled meat have also evolved and now cren (horseradish), salsa verde (a cold parsley-based condiment) and mustard are used, but in the 18th century, as Giuseppe Maffioli diligently points out, they were very different:

It is diluted with a little oil, vinegar (a lot), pepper and lemon. In a small bowl put one egg and one tablespoon of sugar. Beat well. When frothy add a tumbler of vinegar, then transfer to the fire and cook like an eggnog. It is used as well cold as hot. Add a level tablespoon of capers. A handful of white flour is boiled in water or broth to form a floured liquid. Well pounded anchovies and a small piece of butter, salt, spices and the tartness of a lemon are added. It is simmered for another 3 or 4 minutes and sent to the table hot.

  3. In a small bowl put one egg and one tablespoon of sugar. Beat well. When frothy add a tumbler of vinegar, then transfer to the fire and cook like an eggnog. It is used as well cold as hot. Add a level tablespoon of capers.
  4. A handful of white flour is boiled in water or broth to form a floured liquid. Well pounded anchovies and a small piece of butter, salt, spices and the tartness of a lemon are added. It is simmered for another 3 or 4 minutes and sent to the table hot.

item.value: <svg xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><path xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" d="M647.40909,277.46544h78.27273v0h78.27273v24.63636v24.63636h-78.27273h-78.27273v-24.63636z" data-paper-data="{"strokeWidth":1,"rotation":0,"annotation":null,"nonHoverStrokeColor":["Color",0,0.74902,1],"editable":true}" id="rectangle_100f3e34-6655-4c59-8863-c2cd17871734" fill-opacity="0.00001" fill="#00bfff" fill-rule="nonzero" stroke="#00bfff" stroke-width="9.44012" stroke-linecap="butt" stroke-linejoin="miter" stroke-miterlimit="10" stroke-dasharray="" stroke-dashoffset="0" font-family="none" font-weight="none" font-size="none" text-anchor="none" style="mix-blend-mode: normal"/></svg>

resource.http://dev.llgc.org.uk/sas/full_text:
La Minestra (Soup)

This dish was customary when boiled meat arrived on the table immediately afterwards. When the meat was cooked and removed from the broth, it was pureed or at any rate the vegetables and any meat residue were also carefully removed, brought back to a boil, and rice or pasta was added, which was then brought to a simmer. The pasta was generally egg pasta, homemade, of a rather thin format, like tagliatelle or thin, fairly short bigoli. It was flavored at the end with plenty of grated piazentin cheese or even parmesan or old local dairy and sent to the table.
resource.chars:
La Minestra (Soup)

This dish was customary when boiled meat arrived on the table immediately afterwards. When the meat was cooked and removed from the broth, it was pureed or at any rate the vegetables and any meat residue were also carefully removed, brought back to a boil, and rice or pasta was added, which was then brought to a simmer. The pasta was generally egg pasta, homemade, of a rather thin format, like tagliatelle or thin, fairly short bigoli. It was flavored at the end with plenty of grated piazentin cheese or even parmesan or old local dairy and sent to the table.

item.value: <svg xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><path xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" d="M85.27273,800.14325h52.36364v0h52.36364v20.54545v20.54545h-52.36364h-52.36364v-20.54545z" data-paper-data="{"strokeWidth":1,"rotation":0,"deleteIcon":null,"rotationIcon":null,"group":null,"editable":true,"annotation":null}" id="rectangle_dd670c5b-d6a3-4989-a935-9ad6d8e7e2bb" fill-opacity="0" fill="#00bfff" fill-rule="nonzero" stroke="#00bfff" stroke-width="1" stroke-linecap="butt" stroke-linejoin="miter" stroke-miterlimit="10" stroke-dasharray="" stroke-dashoffset="0" font-family="none" font-weight="none" font-size="none" text-anchor="none" style="mix-blend-mode: normal"/></svg>

resource.http://dev.llgc.org.uk/sas/full_text:
Il Lesso (Boiled Meat) 

This is the most popular dish in the bourgeois kitchens of the 18th-century Venice and was prepared with different kinds of meat, especially capon, chicken, turkey, breast and head of veal, mutton and sheep. Meats with a few pieces of bone were placed in a pot with cold water, flavored with a clove-studded onion, one or more stalks of celery, a few carrots, parsley stalks, and one or more cloves of garlic. Once cooked, the meats were kept warm in a nice copper pot, immersed in their broth. When it was time to serve them, they were sent to the table accompanied by special sauces.
resource.chars:
Il Lesso (Boiled Meat) 

This is the most popular dish in the bourgeois kitchens of the 18th-century Venice and was prepared with different kinds of meat, especially capon, chicken, turkey, breast and head of veal, mutton and sheep. Meats with a few pieces of bone were placed in a pot with cold water, flavored with a clove-studded onion, one or more stalks of celery, a few carrots, parsley stalks, and one or more cloves of garlic. Once cooked, the meats were kept warm in a nice copper pot, immersed in their broth. When it was time to serve them, they were sent to the table accompanied by special sauces.

resource.http://dev.llgc.org.uk/sas/full_text:
La salsa par el lesso (Boiled Meat Sauce)

Sauces for boiled meat have also evolved and now cren (horseradish), salsa verde (a cold parsley-based condiment) and mustard are used, but in the 18th century, as Giuseppe Maffioli diligently points out, they were very different:

    A salted and well pounded pilchard and a little garlic, you take a little oil and dilute, add lemon juice and vinegar and mix it all with breadcrumbs and parsley (chopped). Care must be taken that it does not come out too liquid or too thick. (Spicy) Three salted pilchards, two hard-boiled egg yolks, everything is pounded well. It is diluted with a little oil, vinegar (a lot), pepper and lemon. In a small bowl put one egg and one tablespoon of sugar. Beat well. When frothy add a tumbler of vinegar, then transfer to the fire and cook like an eggnog. It is used as well cold as hot. Add a level tablespoon of capers. A handful of white flour is boiled in water or broth to form a floured liquid. Well pounded anchovies and a small piece of butter, salt, spices and the tartness of a lemon are added. It is simmered for another 3 or 4 minutes and sent to the table hot.
resource.chars:
La salsa par el lesso (Boiled Meat Sauce)

Sauces for boiled meat have also evolved and now cren (horseradish), salsa verde (a cold parsley-based condiment) and mustard are used, but in the 18th century, as Giuseppe Maffioli diligently points out, they were very different:

  1. A salted and well pounded pilchard and a little garlic, you take a little oil and dilute, add lemon juice and vinegar and mix it all with breadcrumbs and parsley (chopped). Care must be taken that it does not come out too liquid or too thick.
  2. (Spicy) Three salted pilchards, two hard-boiled egg yolks, everything is pounded well. It is diluted with a little oil, vinegar (a lot), pepper and lemon.
  3. In a small bowl put one egg and one tablespoon of sugar. Beat well. When frothy add a tumbler of vinegar, then transfer to the fire and cook like an eggnog. It is used as well cold as hot. Add a level tablespoon of capers.
  4. A handful of white flour is boiled in water or broth to form a floured liquid. Well pounded anchovies and a small piece of butter, salt, spices and the tartness of a lemon are added. It is simmered for another 3 or 4 minutes and sent to the table hot.
